caption: Sandra Oh accepting the Golden Globe for best performance by an actress in a television series drama for "Killing Eve."

result.explanation: The image shows Sandra Oh holding a Golden Globe award.  She is clearly the focus of the image, accepting the award. The caption accurately reflects this. The words "Killing Eve" are not explicitly visible in the image, but the context strongly suggests it is the show for which she is receiving the award.

candidates.title: Bafta bends the rules for Killing Eve in TV Awards nominations
candidates.content:
BBC thriller Killing Eve leads this year's Bafta TV Award nominations, with its stars Sandra Oh and Jodie Comer both up for best actress.
The show has five nominations for the main awards and nine for Bafta's Craft Awards, which were revealed together.
Bafta allowed the nominations despite the fact that its rules say shows must have been broadcast in the UK first.
Killing Eve premiered in the US on BBC America last April, five months before it arrived on BBC One and the iPlayer.
The spy drama's other acting nominees are Fiona Shaw, who played spymaster Carolyn, and Kim Bodina, who was Villanelle's handler Konstantin. They are up for best supporting actress and supporting actor respectively.
Killing Eve is also in the running for best drama series, while Phoebe Waller-Bridge is nominated for best drama writer.
The top Bafta TV nominees
Killing Eve - 14
A Very English Scandal - 12
Patrick Melrose - 6
Bodyguard - 5
The Little Drummer Girl - 5
Mrs Wilson - 4
Mum - 4
The full list of Bafta TV Awards nominees
Killing Eve's nominations were possible because Bafta bent its own eligibility criteria, which say shows "must have had the worldwide premiere transmission in the UK".
A Bafta spokeswoman said: "Bafta's television committee deems Killing Eve a British series. Killing Eve received 14 nominations, nine of which were eligible under Bafta's criteria, and five of which were deemed eligible by the TV committee due to the significant creative contribution from key UK talent throughout the production. The television committee is the arbiter of all eligibility."
London-based author Luke Jennings, who wrote the books that Killing Eve was based on, said most of the show's creative team, cast and crew were homegrown, as was its sensibility.
"You couldn't have a more British show than Killing Eve," he told BBC Radio 5 Live. "This was a wholly British production and British in conception. They've decided we are eligible and I'm very happy to go with that."
The second series is about to start in the US, and Jennings added: "I'll take a jump and I'll say we're probably going to be seeing season three, yeah."
Bodyguard stars have differing fortunes
Bodyguard's Keeley Hawes will go up against Comer and Oh for best actress - but there was no room on the best actor list for her co-star Richard Madden.
Bodyguard is also up for best drama series, alongside BBC One's Informer, Sky Atlantic's Save Me and Killing Eve.
Hawes is in the running for two trophies after also receiving a best supporting actress nomination for Mrs Wilson.
Allow Twitter content?
This article contains content provided by Twitter . We ask for your permission before anything is loaded, as they may be using cookies and other technologies. You may want to read and before accepting. To view this content choose accept and continue.
Hugh vs Benedict
A Very English Scandal has a total of 12 nominations, including one for Hugh Grant for best actor for playing disgraced Liberal leader Jeremy Thorpe. His co-star Ben Whishaw is up for best supporting actor.
Grant's rivals for best actor are Benedict Cumberbatch for Patrick Melrose, Chance Perdomo for Killed By My Debt and Lucian Msamati for Kiri.
Bafta chairwoman Dame Pippa Harris told the Press Association some "difficult" decisions had been made because there were only four spots up for grabs on each shortlist.
She said: "When you look at those four performances, it's very difficult to say 'Well, which one you would pull out in order to put Richard Madden in there?"'
The unstoppable Ant and Dec
Elsewhere, Ant and Dec are up for best entertainment performance and entertainment programme for Saturday Night Takeaway. Declan Donnelly had to finish presenting last year's series on his own after Ant McPartlin's drink-drive arrest last March.
At last year's ceremony, Ant was missing when Dec accepted the entertainment programme prize for Britain's Got Talent.
BGT is nominated for best entertainment programme alongside Takeaway again this year. Their heavyweight competitors are Strictly Come Dancing and Michael McIntyre's Big Show.
And I'm A Celebrity... Get Me Out Of Here - which Dec hosted with Holly Willoughby last year in Ant's absence - is up for the best reality and constructed factual prize.
Who's up for the comedy awards?
This Country star Daisy May Cooper is in with a shot of winning the best female comedy performance award for the second year in a row.
But she'll face stiff competition from Jessica Hynes for There She Goes, Julia Davis for Sally4Ever and Lesley Manville for Mum.
Sally4Ever and Mum are also up for best scripted comedy, alongside Derry Girls and Stath Lets Flats - both Channel 4 shows.
But the Car Share finale didn't make it on to the list, with Peter Kay and Sian Gibson also missing out in the comedy performance categories.
However, they are up for best comedy writing and the show is up for the must-see moment prize, which will be voted for by the public.
Other notable nominations and snubs
Documentary Bros: After the Screaming Stops and Black Mirror's choose your own adventure-style film Bandersnatch are among the productions with three nominations.
On the best actress shortlist, Ruth Wilson is nominated for playing her own grandmother in Mrs Wilson.
As well as being nominated for Killing Eve, Jodie Comer's 15-minute BBC Four drama Bovril Pam - part of a series of eight short monologues written and performed by women - is up for the short-form award.
There was no nomination for Jodie Whittaker for her first season as the first female Doctor Who.
Good Morning Britain has its first Bafta nominations - named twice in the best news coverage category for its special on knife crime and its exclusive interview with Meghan Markle's father.
There's no place for Emmerdale on the soap and continuing drama shortlist, despite the fact it has won the National TV Awards' serial drama prize for three years in a row. Instead, the Bafta list has last year's winner Casualty plus Coronation Street, EastEnders and Hollyoaks.
The main Bafta Television Awards will be handed out on 12 May at the Royal Festival Hall in London and the ceremony will be shown on BBC One.
candidates.description: The spy thriller leads the TV awards nominations, despite not meeting the entry criteria.

result.explanation: The provided text focuses on BAFTA awards nominations for "Killing Eve", mentioning Sandra Oh's nomination for best actress.  There is no mention of Sandra Oh winning a Golden Globe for this role in the provided text.  Therefore, the news caption cannot be verified with the given evidence.

final_result.explanation: The internal validation check shows high confidence (score 10) that the caption accurately reflects the image, based on Sandra Oh's pose and the presence of a Golden Globe award. However, the external validation check has zero confidence and finds no supporting evidence. This discrepancy arises because the external check focuses on BAFTA nominations for "Killing Eve," while the caption refers to a Golden Globe win for the same role.  The image alone cannot definitively confirm or deny whether the award is a Golden Globe.  Without external corroboration specifying the award ceremony as the Golden Globes, and given the conflict in sources, the caption is deemed out of context. The low confidence score reflects this uncertainty stemming from the lack of clear external evidence confirming the award is a Golden Globe, despite strong internal visual support.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal validation strongly supports the caption, but the absence of external verification regarding the Golden Globe award leaves the claim uncertain. The discrepancy between internal visual evidence and the lack of external evidence leads to a low confidence score and an out-of-context assessment.
